Participants.evidence: Twenty-four study participants (medical students in their final year of school, who were applying to surgery residency programs, and who had no prior arthroplasty experience)

Intervention.evidence: One group trained using AR (with live holographic orientation feedback) and the other received one-on-one training from a hip arthroplasty surgeon.

Objective.evidence: does an AR headset improve the accuracy of acetabular component positioning compared with hands-on training by an expert surgeon?

Method_Outcome.evidence: The orientation error in degrees between the planned and achieved orientations was measured

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomized to two groups

Result_Outcome.evidence: surgeon group mean improvement 6°, 95% CI, 4–8°; p < 0.001 versus AR group 9°, 95% CI 7–10°; p < 0.001
